Even the best secret agents carry a debt from a past mission. Rachel Singer must now face up to hers...<\/p>

Filmed on location in Tel Aviv, the U.K., and Budapest, the espionage thriller The Debt<\/em><\/strong> is directed by Academy Award nominee John Madden (Shakespeare in Love<\/em>). The screenplay, by Matthew Vaughn & Jane Goldman and Peter Straughan, is adapted from the 2007 Israeli film Ha-Hov <\/em>[The Debt<\/em><\/strong>]. At the 2011 Beaune International Thriller Film Festival, The Debt<\/em> was honored with the Special Police [Jury] Prize.<\/p>

The story begins in 1997, as shocking news reaches retired Mossad secret agents Rachel (played by Academy Award winner Helen Mirren) and Stephan (two-time Academy Award nominee Tom Wilkinson) about their former colleague David (Ciar'an Hinds of the upcoming Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy<\/em>). All three have been venerated for decades by Israel because of the secret mission that they embarked on for their country back in 1965-1966, when the trio (portrayed, respectively, by Jessica Chastain [The Tree of Life<\/em>, The Help<\/em>], Marton Csokas [The Lord of the Rings<\/em>, Dream House<\/em>], and Sam Worthington [Avatar<\/em>, Clash of the Titans<\/em>]) tracked down Nazi war criminal Dieter Vogel (Jesper Christensen of Casino Royale<\/em> and Quantum of Solace<\/em>), the feared Surgeon of Birkenau, in East Berlin. While Rachel found herself grappling with romantic feelings during the mission, the net around Vogel was tightened by using her as bait.<\/p>

At great risk, and at considerable personal cost, the team's mission was accomplished - or was it? The suspense builds in and across two different time periods, with startling action and surprising revelations that compel Rachel to take matters into her own hands.<\/p>","in_theaters":"
